title: OUTDOORS BRIEFS: Long-awaited snow should be boon for regional ski hills
text:
Snow has finally started to accumulate in decent numbers at regional ski areas and may save what has so far been a frustrating season for winter sports enthusiasts. There should be plenty of powder this weekend, but bundle up, it’s going to be cold.
Conditions as of Thursday:
Ski Bluewood — Six inches of fresh powder with more on the way.
Brundage — It’s snowing and there is 5 inches of powder on the slopes. Four of six lifts and about half of the trails are open.
Lookout Pass — Snowing with 8 inches of fresh powder.
Silver Mountain — Just 1 inch of new snow over the last day but the area was hit with 16 inches earlier this week.
Schweitzer — Two inches of new snow since Wednesday on top of 12 inches earlier in the week.
Tamarack — Three inches of new snow on top of 17 inches earlier this week.
Bald Mountain — Plan to open Jan. 20 if these storms deliver enough snow.
Cottonwood Butte — Not open, waiting for more snow.
Snowhaven — Getting closer but not open year.
Cross-Country
Fields Spring State Park — Fresh snow. Grooming has begun.
Palouse Divide — Enough snow to ski.
Ponderosa State Park — Partially groomed.
Lolo Pass — Not groomed but 8 to 12 inches of fresh snow.
Palouse Divide club invites people to learn cross-country skiing
PALOUSE DIVIDE — People interested in cross-country skiing can learn for free at the Palouse Divide Nordic Ski Area here Saturday.
The Palouse Divide Nordic Ski Club is hosting free cross-country ski lessons from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. The group will provide hot drinks and tend warming fires at the trailhead and at a warming hut.
Cross-country gear swap planned next week
MOSCOW — The Palouse Divide Nordic Ski Club will host a cross-country gear swap from 6:30-8:30 p.m. Wednesday at the 1912 Center’s Arts Workshop, 412 E. Third St., Moscow.
People are encouraged to bring their used Nordic ski gear and snowshoeing equipment, especially parents with children who have grown out of their equipment. Those who bring gear to sell or swap are responsible for managing their transactions. Registration is not required but the club is asking people to RSVP to .
Trails in central Idaho wilderness area the topic of presentation next week
MOSCOW — Jim Heidelberger will speak about the Selway Bitterroot-Frank Church Foundation and its work to steward trails in central Idaho wilderness areas at a Clearwater Fly Casters meeting at the Best Western University Inn Plus here Wednesday.
Heidelberger is the chairperson of the group that works with the U.S. Forest Service to do trail work and other stewardship activities in the Selway Bitterroot and Frank Church River of No Return wilderness areas.
The evening begins at 5:30 p.m. with a social hour followed by a $21 buffet meal at 6:30 and Heidelberger’s presentation at 7:30.
Bighorn sheep numbers appear stable in Big Creek drainage
BOISE — The bighorn sheep herd in the Big Creek drainage off of the Middle Fork of the Salmon River in central Idaho appears to be stable, according to an Idaho Fish and Game survey.
Surveyors from the University of Idaho, Idaho Wild Sheep Foundation and the department counted 75 wild sheep downstream of Cabin Creek in the remote wilderness area. The tally is consistent with population counts in previous surveys, according to a news release. The ratio of 34 lambs per 100 ewes was slightly above average. The agency recorded a ratio of 61 rams per 100 ewes during the count.
Boating safety class planned next month
The Nez Perce County Sheriff’s deputies will teach an Idaho Boat Safety Class from 8 a.m. to 2 p.m. Feb. 25 at the sheriff’s office near Lewiston.
Those would like to register for the class or learn more about it can contact Dep. Darreck Wilkinson at (208) 750-2088 ext. 4532.
Hunting guide to share stories about his career in Selway backcountry
KOOSKIA — Legendary hunting guide and packer Jim Renshaw will share stories about his life in the Selway River backcountry during a talk at the Kooskia Community Center on Feb. 24.
The 1 p.m. talk is sponsored by the Friends of the Kooskia Community Library.
As a 2-month-old in 1932, Jim Renshaw traveled with his family deep into the Selway River country for the first time. The second-generation packer subsequently spent many years living a life many only dream about. Renshaw will share stories and photos about his life in the backcountry.
The library will be open from noon to 2:30 p.m. and crafts will be available for kids during the presentation. Refreshments will be provided.
